Abstract Density functional theory (DFT) calculations have been performed for adsorption of guanine (a nucleobase) on the surface of Al12N12 (AlN), Al12P12 (AlP), B12N12 (BN), and B12P12 (BP) nano-cages. The interaction of guanine with nano-cages is highly exothermic (chemisorption), and the adsorption energies are in order of AlN>AlP>BN>BP. Although AlN has the highest adsorption energy; however, BN and BP show more changes in electronic property upon adsorption of guanine. The results of charge analysis, density of states (DOSs), and frontier molecular orbital, confirm a distinguished orbital hybridization upon adsorption of guanine, which suggest potential application of BN as biochemical adsorbent for guanine.
Key words: Guanine, nano-cages, Al12N12, Al12P12, B12N12, B12P12, DFT

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Adsorption of nucleosides and nucleotides molecules on proper surfaces is quite important in biological technologies [1]. Several free nucleic acids exist in the environment, and commonly known as ‘‘nucleic acid library’’ for microorganisms via transformation [2].A nucleotide has a nitrogenous base, commonly known as nucleobase, connected to a sugar molecule. Nucleotides are the building blocks of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and ribonucleic acid (RNA).Therefore, the adsorption of nucleic acids and nucleobases on different surfaces is very important, and several studies demonstrate adsorption of the nucleotide molecules on different surfaces [3-7]. Application of diverse adsorbents for biological molecules has been widely studied. For example, Saikia and Deka [8] demonstrated the adsorption of 2-methyl-heptyl-isonicotinate (anti-tubercular drug) on the surface of functionalized carbon nanotube. Arsawang et al. [9] investigated the gemcitabine transportation in a drug delivery system using carbon nanotube. Schmidt et al. have investigated the adsorption properties of adenine on coinage metal (1 1 0) surfaces [10]. Furukawa et al. theoretically analyzed the geometrical properties of adenine and guanine on the surface of Cu (1 1 0) [11]. Ramraj et al. [12] investigated the adsorption of nucleic acids on carbon nanotubes via approximate quantum chemical methods. Stepanian et al. studied the interaction of cytosine with carbon nanotubes by using MP2, DFT and Raman spectroscopy [13]. Currently, non-metal [14, 15] and metal included nanostructures [16-21] have been used extensively as adsorbent/sensor for different analytes. In our previous work, [16] we used Aldoped graphene as a superior adsorbent for acetyl halide molecules whereas pristine graphene shows very little response for acetyl halide. Furthermore, the application of Al-doped graphene as gas sensor for some ether molecules was also examined [17].The Al-doped graphene has high adsorption ability for ether molecules. Al-doped graphene has also been

studied theoretically for its sensing ability for NO2 and N2O [18] CO, CO2 and H2O [19] and some halomethane molecules [20]. Moreover, adsorption properties of Pt decorated graphene for NO[21] and C2H2, and C2H4[22] have also been studied. Beside graphene based materials, much attention has been paid recently to the XnYn(X = Group III, Y = Group IV elements) nanostructures [1]. Notable chemical and physical properties are expected for these nano-materials such as large gap semiconductors. Al12N12, AlN, AlP, BN and BP are four main nano-cages, and they are important not only for their special adsorption capability but also for low electron attraction, large HOMO-LUMO gap and outstanding physical as well as chemical properties [23–26].
There are many reports on adsorption properties of different molecules on the outer surface of AlN, AlP, BN and BP nano-cages. For example, Ahmadi et al. studied the adsorption energies of carbon monoxide and NO on AlN and BN systems [27,28]. Beheshtian et al. [29] performed a DFT study of the interaction of a hydrogen atom with BP nano-cluster. The results revel that electron density of adsorbing atoms has an important role in the H adsorption on the BPnano-cage. Soltani et al. [30] studied the adsorption of phenol with different nano-cages using DFT. The hydrogen storage ability of Ni decorated AlN cluster has been investigated by Huang et al. [31]. Shakerzadeh et al. [32] reported a comparative theoretical study on the electronic properties of BN and AlN.
Based on our knowledge, the adsorption of guanine has not been studied on these nano-cages. Here, we present our results on DFT study of adsorption of guanine molecule on the surfaces AlN, AlP, BN, and BP fullerene-like cages. Guanine is one of the four nucleobases which exist in the nucleic acids of DNA and RNA, The relaxed structure of adsorbent-guanine, the values of adsorption energy, charge transfers, and density of states (DOSs) of the systems were calculated and analyzed.

sections.heading: 2. Computational methods
sections.text:
In this study, we searched on the adsorption behavior of the guanine on the surfaces of AlN, AlP, BN, and BP nano-cages. Geometry optimizations, charge analysis, density of states (DOSs), and frontier molecular orbital calculations are performed using Gaussian 09 program package [33]at B3LYP/6–31G(d,p) level of DFT. The geometry optimizations were performed without any constraints under default parameters (for optimization) in Gaussian 09. The default grid for optimization in G09 is fine. The maximum force and RMS forces are 3 x 10-4 and 4.5 x 10-4 (Hartrees/Bohr and Hartrees/Radian) whereas maximum displacement and RMS displacement are 1.8 x 10-3 and 1.2 x 10-3.
The B3LYP method of DFT has been applied by us and others to study the geometries and interaction details of sensors with a variety of analytes [34-39] The adsorption energy of Guanine on the AlN, AlP, BN, and BP nano-cages are specified through as follow: Eads= ENanocage-guanine- (ENanocage + Eguanine) (1) where ENanocage-guanine is the total (electronic) energy of the nano-cage (AlN or AlP or BN or BP) interacting with the guanine and ENanocage is total energy of isolated nano-cage (AlN or AlP or BN or BP),and Eguanine is the total energy of an isolated guanine. The electrophilicity concept was stated for the first time in 1999 by Parr et al. [40]. Chemical potential (µ) is defined based the subsequent equation [41]: µ=−(EHOMO+ELUMO)/2 (2) where EHOMO is the energy of HOMO and ELUMO is the energy of LUMO. In addition, hardness (ŋ) can be calculated using the Koopmans’ theorem [41] as: ŋ = (ELUMO – EHOMO)/2 (3) Softness (S) [41] and electrophilicity (ω) [41] are explained as the subsequent equations, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.1. Study on the structure of relaxed systems
sections.text:
The optimized geometries of pure AlN, AlP, BN and BP nano-cages show that each nanocage is composed of four and six membered rings. The geometric parameters for optimized geometries in this study agree with the already reported data [26]. The geometric parameters of these pure nano-cages have already been described in the literature; therefore, a detailed description is not provided here. We restrict our description of structures to those geometric parameters which are not well discussed previously. It is worth mentioning that both rings (four and six membered) are not completely planar. For example in AlN (Al12N12), the dihedral angle Al-N-Al-N in four membered ring (Ring A in Figure 1) is 10.70˚(puckered) whereas the corresponding dihedral angle in six membered ring (Ring B, Figure 1) is -18.39˚ degree (slightly chair like). For other cages, this deformation from planarity increases; the dihedral angles in four and six membered ring are 12.18˚ and -24.95˚ (BN nano-cage), 23.99˚ and -41.33˚ (BP nano-cage), and -26.83˚ and -45.51˚ (AlP nano-cage), respectively.

Moreover the bond angles in four and six membered rings for these nano-cages are analyzed, and important geometric parameters are given in Table 1. The X-Y-X (X = Al, B and Y = N or P, see Figure 1 for labeling) bond angle is always smaller than the Y-X-Y bond angle. For AlN nano-cage, Al-N-Al bond angles are 84.45˚ and 112.54˚ in four and six membered rings, respectively. On the other hand, N-Al-N bond angles are 94.53˚ and 125.79˚ degrees in four and six membered rings, respectively. The bond angles in the four membered ring are decreased in the case of BN nano-cage (compared to AlN nano-cage) whereas the bond angles in six membered ring are either increased or unaffected. The B-N-B angles are 80.51˚ (4 membered ring) and 110.99˚ (six membered ring) whereas the corresponding N-B-N bond angles are 98.19˚ and 125.80˚ respectively. For the four membered ring of AlP nano-cage, the Al-P-Al and P-Al-P bond angles are 74.69˚ and 98.92˚, respectively. The corresponding bond angles in the six membered ring of AlP nano-cage are 99.34˚ and 130.13 degrees. For the BP nano-cage, the bond angles are comparable to the AlP nano-cage.

The interaction of guanine with these nano-cages can be described in terms of binding energy and changes in geometric parameters. A list of important geometric parameters along with charge analyses and binding energies is given in Table 2. The binding energies of guanine with AlN, AlP, BN and BP are -207.5, -158.1, -127.8 and -

93.9 kj mol-1, respectively. Moreover, the binding distance of guanine with AlN, AlP, BN and BP are 1.86Å, 1.87Å, 1.53Å and 1.53Å, respectively. Although binding energies are remarkably different between AlN and AlP or BN and BP nano-cages, however, the interaction distances are not different. The high binding energies are indicative of chemisorption of guanine on these nano-cages. The highest binding energy of guanine is observed for AlN nano-cage followed by AlP. In general, the binding of guanine is higher for Al nano-cages compared to boron nano-cages, and it can be attributed to the higher charge density on Al than B (vide infra).
Nano-cages interact with carbonyl oxygen atom of guanine. Aluminum, being more electropositive than boron, interacts strongly with the oxygen of guanine. For AlN, the charge on aluminum is +1.84 which is much higher than +0.44 for boron in BN nano-cage. Among aluminum cages, the charge of AlN (1.84) is higher than the corresponding AlP nano-cage. The higher interaction energies of nitrogen containing nano-cages compared to phosphorus can be explained on the basis of higher charge density and hydrogen bonding interaction in the former (vide infra). It is interesting to note that the charge (+ive) on nano-cages increases after interaction with guanine. The increase in charge is more pronounced for BN than other nano-cages. The interaction energies of guanine on these nano-cages are considerably higher than the adsorption of other nucleobases (adenosine, cytocine and uracil). M. T. Baeiet. al.[1] have shown that interaction energies (calculated at B3LYP/6-31G(d)) for the adsorption of adenosine, cytocine and uracil are -183.3 kj mol-1 (-1.90 eV), -189.1 kj mol-1 (-1.96 eV) and - 163.1 kj mol-1 (-1.69 eV) on AlN nano-cage, considerably lower than -207.5 kj mol-1 for adsorption of guanine on AlN. However, interaction energies of adenosine, cytocine and uracil on BN nano-cages are -139.9 kj mol-1 (-1.45 eV), -128.3 kj mol-1 (-1.33 eV) and -78.1 kj mol-1 (-0.81 eV), comparable to adsorption energy of guanine on BN nano-cage.

The optimized structure of guanine-complexes of different nano-cages Adsorption of guanine causes significant changes in the geometries of nano-cages, and this effect vanishes off with the distance from point of adsorption. The chemisorption (as evident from binding energies) causes change in hybridization of aluminum and boron (of nanocages) from sp2 to sp3 which causes the aluminum and boron atoms to be protruded out of the cage. The change in geometry affects all geometric parameters including bond length, bond angles and dihedral angles. It is very difficult to discuss all structural changes in these nanocages therefore, only limited structural parameters are analyzed and given in Table 1.For example, in pure AlN nano-cage, the Al-N bond distance in four membered ring is 1.86A° whereas in guanine-AlN complex, all four bond lengths in the four membered ring become different i.e., 1.99Å, 1.89Å, 1.86Å and 1.82Å. Since it is difficult to list all changes in a table therefore, only selected geometric parameters (with more significant changes) are shown in Table 2. A neighboring nitrogen atom (to Aluminum) shows non-bonding interactions with the amide hydrogen of guanine at a distance of 1.56Å (Figure 3). The guanine N-H bond is also significantly elongated (1.10Å, Figure 3). Since the nitrogen atom of AlN nano-cage is involved in hydrogen bonding with guanine therefore, as a consequence, bonding of this nitrogen with aluminum in the cage is weakened and it results in enlarged bond length

sections.heading: 3.2. Electronic properties and relative stabilities
sections.text:
In order to better understand the adsorption process of guanine on these nano-cages, frontier molecular orbitals (HOMO and LUMO) are analyzed before and after adsorption. The frontier molecular orbitals are given in Figure 4. Energies of HOMO and LUMO of AlN nano-cage are -6.47 and -2.54 eV with a Fermi level of -4.50 eV. The band gap in AlN is 3.93 eV. The HOMO in AlN nano-cage is mostly located on nitrogen atoms whereas the LUMO has density uniformly distributed on all atoms. Upon interaction with guanine, significant
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
12
changes are observed in HOMO and LUMO. In AlN-G complex, the HOMO is further localized to a few nitrogen atoms whereas the density in LUMO is slightly localized at a position away from the site of interaction. Upon interaction with guanine, energies of HOMO and LUMO are increased to -5.84 and 3.98 eV, respectively whereas the band gap is decreased from 3.93 to 3.72 eV. A similar drop in the band gap (from 3.39 to 3.18 eV) is also observed for adsorption of guanine on AlP nano-cage. The HOMO and LUMO of pure AlP has distribution of density similar to AlN however, a small difference is observed on interaction with guanine. The HOMO in AlP-G complex is located on phosphorus atoms close to the binding site whereas the LUMO is located on Al and P atoms away from the binding site (see figure 4 for details). Among boron nano-cages (BN and BP), the behavior of the latter (BP) is very similar to AlP, although the effect on the band gap is relatively large. The band gap for BP-G nano-cage is 3.31 eV compared to 3.70 for BP nano-cage. A remarkably different behavior is observed for adsorption of guanine on BN nano-cage. BN nano-cage has relatively high band gap of 6.85 eV. The energies of HOMO and LUMO are -7.71 and 0.86 eV. HOMO in BN nano-cage is very similar to other nano-cages, and it is located on certain nitrogen atoms. However, the LUMO is centered mainly on boron atoms. In BN-G complex, the HOMO density is shared between guanine and BN moieties, although more density on the latter. The LUMO on BN-G complex is located entirely on the guanine part. This behavior of BN nano-cages towards adsorption of guanine can be partly attributed to better overlap of orbitals, probably due to similar band gap of BN and guanine. The Fermi levels of pristine AlN, AlP, BN and BP change from -4.5, -5.05, -4.28 and -6.54eV to -3.98, -4.39, -4.05 and -4.08 eV in guanine complexes, respectively (Table 3). The adsorption of guanine on the nano-cages has significant effect on the dipole moment. The dipole moments of all pristine nano-cages are essentially zero whereas the dipole

sections.heading: 3.3. Quantum molecular descriptors
sections.text:
The global indices of reactivity for guanine, pristine nano-cages and guanine adsorbed nanocages are given in Table 4. The global indices of reactivity are quite important parameters because they illustrate the reactivity and stability of a molecule or complex. Guanine is relatively harder (2.75 eV) compared to nano-cages studied. Interestingly, the hardness for the nano-cages decreases on complexation. For Al nano-cage, the change in hardness is relatively small (∆ŋ = - 0.10eV) whereas significantly large changes are observed for BN (∆ŋ =-0.95) and BP (∆ŋ= -0.2) nano-cages. These trends are consistent with the changes in band gap and Mullikan charges of nano-cages upon adsorption of guanine. The highest effect is observed for BN followed by BP nano-cages. Since hardness is a measure of stability of a chemical system towards deformation in the presence of electrical field; therefore, the guanine nano-cage complexes are more prone to changes under electrical field compared to pristine nano-cages. Softness changes reciprocal to the hardness, therefore, it is expected that softness for these complexes will increase. Changes in softness on adsorption of guanine with AlN, AlP, BN and BP are 0.2, 0.2, 0.5 and 0.3eV, respectively.

Towards further understanding of interaction of guanine with these nano-cages, density of states (DOS) of pristine nano-cages and guanine adsorbed nano-cages have also been studied. The density of states of a particular nano-cage is compared in its pure and guanine adsorbed geometry in parallel (see Figure 5). Upon interaction with guanine, some new energy states appear near Fermi level for all complexes which cause decrease in Eg values. The highest change in Eg is observed for BN-Guanine complex (∆Eg = 1.90) followed by BP-Guanine complex (∆Eg = 0.39). The change is Eg for BN-G complex is expected to cause significant changes in electrical conductivity because Eg (for bulk materials) is a prime factor in determining the electrical conductivity of a material. Relationship between conductivity and Eg can be given by the following equation where it can be seen clearly that a small decrease in Eg leads to significantly higher electrical conductivities.
σ ∝ exp (-Eg/2KT) (6)
where σ defined as the electric conductivity and k defined as the Boltzmann constant [42]
For Boron nano-cage, not only the change in Eg is higher but also the effect on intensities is
also more pronounced. The biggest change in intensities is observed for LUMO in BN-G complex. For BP nano-cage, the intensities of both occupied and virtual orbital are changed on complexation with guanine. Although higher interaction energies are observed for Al nano-cages (AlN and AlP) compared to boron nano-cages (BN and BP); however, the effect on Eg and DOS is relatively small. These observations clearly imply that the AlP and AlN are not good sensors for guanine. The highest sensitivity towards guanine is expected for BN nano-cage. 3.4 Molecular Electrostatic potential

The molecular electrostatic potentials have also been studied to better understand the binding sites. For this purpose, MEP of guanine, AlN, AlP, BN, BP nano-cages and their complexes AlN-G, AlP-G, BN-G and BP-G are studiedand are given in Figure 6. For guanine, the highest negative charge resides on oxygen (red color) therefore; it is the most suitable site for interaction with the nano-cages. For nano-cages, Al and B are positively charged (blue color) whereas the phosphorus and nitrogen are negatively charged. The negative charge on N and P in the nano-cages is not very pronounced (yellow color). The charge density is more pronounced in nitrogen containing complexes compared to phosphorus. Similarly, Al nanocages show more charge density than boron nano-cages. These finding suggest that a large charge transfer takes places from electropositive atom (B or Al) to electronegative atom (oxygen of guanine). After interaction, the negative charge intensity of guanine and positive charge density on X (B or Al) decrease, as expected.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The B3LYP/6-31G(d,p) method was applied to investigate guanine interaction with Al12N12, Al12P12, B12N12, and B12P12 nano-cages. After fully structural relaxation of the most stable configurations, binding energy, equilibrium distance and some important physical parameters were investigated.The highest interaction energy of guanine was obtained for Al12N12while interaction of guanine with B12N12 and B12P12 reveal higher electronic changes. Charge analyses along with the plots of molecular electrostatic potential showed that the electronic properties of all nano-cages were strongly affected upon adsorption of guanine. Moreover, the density of states and HOMO-LUMO distributions show remarkable orbital hybridization between guanine and these nano-cages. As a result, all these nano-structures are promising candidates for sensing of guanine molecule, while B12N12 can be selected as the most sensitive sensor for guanine adsorptions.
